Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Highly-Efficient Adaptive Wireless Power Transmission and Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal involves wireless power transmission (WPT) that can be used to either continuously power up a device or intermittently recharge its battery without any direct electrical contact between the energy source and that device. The typical users will be researchers that currently have difficulties in conducting behavioral research on small freely behaving animal models with today's technologies. In animal research, long-term biological data acquisition, stimulation, and drug delivery are necessary, and involve cables connected between sensors or electrodes attached to or implanted in the animal body and rack-mounted data acquisition and processing devices, leading to constraints on animal movements and behavior. The proposed technology allows uninterrupted animal experiments in enriched experimental arenas with arbitrary shapes and dimensions.

By providing a large wirelessly-powered and communicated experimental arena, called the EnerCage system, the proposed innovative solution is expected to allow researchers to design experiments that are not possible with today's bio-instruments. The 'EnerCage' system is capable of conforming to experimental arenas with arbitrary shapes and dimensions, and creating a focused magnetic field distribution across these arbitrary shaped arenas by utilizing an array of overlapping hexagonal planar spiral coils, closed-loop control of the received power, dual-band wireless data communication, and wireless non-line-of-sight tracking of the animal subjects via an array of magnetic sensors. The EnerCage system will enable uninterrupted neural interfacing with freely behaving animals in large experimental arenas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every new drug or medical device needs to be tested on animal subjects to show its positive effect and safety before being considered for humans in a clinical study. The most popular animal subjects for this purpose are small mammals, such as rodents, because they are close enough to humans, while costing much less to breed and maintain than larger animal species, such as pigs or monkeys. In these animal experiments, long-term data acquisition, stimulation, and/or drug delivery are often necessary on multiple animals in parallel.

Today’s technology involves cables connected between sensors on the animal body and large instruments, leading to constraints on animal movements and affecting their natural behavior. Therefore, in order to make the results of these pre-clinical experiments more accurate, there is a significant need for a novel system that can alleviate most limitations that researchers are dealing with when they use today’s instruments: 1) Limited range over which the animal can move, 2) Limited number of animals that can be tested at a time while avoiding their cables being entangled, 3) Biased animal behavior due to the stress and annoyance of the cables or weight of the batteries, 4) Motion artifacts and interference resulted from the cables, 5) Unnatural environments for animals due to the small size of the cage and lack of tunnels and closed chambers, which is much closer to the rodents’ natural habitat, 6) Limited duration of the experiment, and 7) The need for animal handling and multiple transfers from the experimental space to the animal facility and back, which is stressful for animals and can further impact the research outcomes.

The main objective of this project is to design, develop, and assess the commercialization potential of a new state-of-the-art scientific research instruments in the form of a wireless, scalable, and smart experimental arena, called the EnerCage system, which utilizes adaptive and efficient wireless power and data transmission to deliver energy and communicate with sensing, stimulating, or drug delivery devices that are attached to or implanted in the animal body in behavioral research experiments on awake freely behaving small animal subjects, particularly rodents. We intend to utilize the abundant processing power of today’s computers and rapid progress in wireless power and data transmission to address the most pressing needs of the scientific research community in the field of behavioral monitoring, combined with fully-automated manipulation and continuous data acquisition from freely behaving animal subjects under test. This research and resulting technology, can not only generate much larger quantities of data in a shorter period of time, it also improves the quality of the collected data. If the EnerCage system becomes commercially available, it can also help many small and large medical device and pharmaceutical companies in the preclinical stage, and reduce the cost of new drugs and medical device development by preventing the need for multiple repeated studies.

In terms of broader impacts, a wide variety of technologies and devices can benefit from highly efficient wireless power transmission (WPT), such as wireless charging of mobile electronics from charging pads and furniture (phones, laptops, tablets), wireless powering of home appliances from walls and countertops (TV’s, audio systems, blenders), wireless charging of electric vehicles and mobile robots in the garage and industrial complexes, and powering medical devices, sensors, and actuators that are used in harsh environments with limited physical access. Wireless power makes such devices/systems more convenient, reliable, safe, environmentally sound, and in some cases even cheaper by eliminating the power cords, connectors, wires, and batteries.

 


...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Every new drug or medical device needs to be tested on animal subjects to show its positive effect and safety before being considered for humans in a clinical study. The most popular animal subjects for this purpose are small mammals, such as rodents, because they are close enough to humans, while costing much less to breed and maintain than larger animal species, such as pigs or monkeys. In these animal experiments, long-term data acquisition, stimulation, and/or drug delivery are often necessary on multiple animals in parallel. TodayÆs technology involves cables connected between sensors on the animal body and large instruments, leading to constraints on animal movements and affecting their natural behavior. Therefore, in order to make the results of these pre-clinical experiments more accurate, there is a significant need for a novel system that can alleviate most limitations that researchers are dealing with when they use todayÆs instruments: 1) Limited range over which the animal can move, 2) Limited number of animals that can be tested at a time while avoiding their cables being entangled, 3) Biased animal behavior due to the stress and annoyance of the cables or weight of the batteries, 4) Motion artifacts and interference resulted from the cables, 5) Unnatural environments for animals due to the small size of the cage and lack of tunnels and closed chambers, which is much closer to the rodentsÆ natural habitat, 6) Limited duration of the experiment, and 7) The need for animal handling and multiple transfers from the experimental space to the animal facility and back, which is stressful for animals and can further impact the research outcomes. The main objective of this project is to design, develop, and assess the commercialization potential of a new state-of-the-art scientific research instruments in the form of a wireless, scalable, and smart experimental arena, called the EnerCage system, which utilizes adaptive and efficient wireless power and data transmission to deliver energy and communicate with sensing, stimulating, or drug delivery devices that are attached to or implanted in the animal body in behavioral research experiments on awake freely behaving small animal subjects, particularly rodents. We intend to utilize the abundant processing power of todayÆs computers and rapid progress in wireless power and data transmission to address the most pressing needs of the scientific research community in the field of behavioral monitoring, combined with fully-automated manipulation and continuous data acquisition from freely behaving animal subjects under test. This research and resulting technology, can not only generate much larger quantities of data in a shorter period of time, it also improves the quality of the collected data. If the EnerCage system becomes commercially available, it can also help many small and large medical device and pharmaceutical companies in the preclinical stage, and reduce the cost of new drugs and medical device development by preventing the need for multiple repeated studies. In terms of broader impacts, a wide variety of technologies and devices can benefit from highly efficient wireless power transmission (WPT), such as wireless charging of mobile electronics from charging pads and furniture (phones, laptops, tablets), wireless powering of home appliances from walls and countertops (TVÆs, audio systems, blenders), wireless charging of electric vehicles and mobile robots in the garage and industrial complexes, and powering medical devices, sensors, and actuators that are used in harsh environments with limited physical access. Wireless power makes such devices/systems more convenient, reliable, safe, environmentally sound, and in some cases even cheaper by eliminating the power cords, connectors, wires, and batteries.
